metadata.title: Sacroiliac Joint Dysfunction
description: The sacroiliac joint (SIJ) has hyaline cartilage lining the sacral side, fibrocartilage lining the iliac side, and a fibrous capsule encompassing the entire joint(1,2,26)
The SIJ is generally C-shaped,  with two lever arms that interlock at the second sacral level, and contains many ridges and depressions, indicating its function for stability more than motion(26)

A large network of ligaments surrounds the SIJ and provides the majority of its stability.(1,26) The deep anterior, posterior, and interosseous ligaments resist the load of the sacrum relative to the ilium; the more superficial ligaments (e.g., the sacrotuberous ligament, long and short sacroiliac ligaments) react to dynamic motions. The long dorsal ligament can become stretched in periods of reduced lumbar lordosis(26)

The SIJ transmits vertical forces between the lower extremities and the spine.(2) SIJ dysfunction may involve a hypermobile or hypomobile condition (e.g., decreased or increased trunk lateral flexion) associated with nonspecific low back pain (LBP) and/or pelvic girdle pain

The prevalence of SIJ dysfunction is estimated to vary between 5% and 30% among patients reporting LBP.(5) A differential diagnosis is usually conducted to rule out other more common causes of LBP before treating SIJ dysfunction, which is mainly a diagnosis of exclusion(5,6)
Conservative treatment for pain linked to SIJ dysfunction includes non-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), modification of physical activities, physical therapy, and use of an SIJ belt in some cases

presentation signs and symptoms: Patients usually report a dull ache that is present in the low back, although rarely above the beltline and usually below the posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS) in a 3 x 10 cm rectangular pattern.(1,3) It can also radiate into the pelvis, groin, gluteal region, thigh, or calf.(2,3) Authors of a study (N = 50 patients, 18 men and 32 women) in the United States found 18 patterns of pain referral using positive SIJ injection blocks with a pain diagram and a visual analog scale (V AS). 94% had buttock pain, 72.0% had lower lumbar pain, and 28.0% had leg pain distal to the knee(7)
Although patients with other causes of nonspecific LBP may describe a similar pain referral pattern, those with SIJ dysfunction usually have minimal or no symptoms in the ischial tuberosity region(3)
Symptoms are four times more likely to be unilateral than bilateral
Numbness, clicking, or popping are sometimes reported in the area of the SIJ(2)
Tenderness may be found along or below the SIJ line(1,2,35)
Weight-bearing  activities of daily living (ADLs) such as walking, running, and stair climbing may increase symptoms(8,29)
Sitting and bending at the waist may also aggravate pain,(9) as may standing and/or bending after sitting for an extended period of time(28) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Perianal paresthesia or loss of bowel/bladder control may indicate a medical emergency. This may be due to a large herniation onto the cauda equina (i.e., cauda equina syndrome) that is below the termination of the spinal cord.(9) (See Clinical Review…Cauda Equina Syndrome ; Topic ID Number: T708499)

Patients with a known family history of cancer, unexplained weight loss, or persistent pain lasting more than 30 days should receive further medical evaluation and review of systems to rule out metastatic disease(9)

causes: Direct fall on or other severe trauma to the hip, sacrum, or buttocks that causes pelvic torsion.(1) Patients with SIJdysfunction often report a precipitating traumatic event(1,2,35)

Any asymmetrical motion of the pelvis, such as from leg-length discrepancy, a unilaterally weak lower extremity, tightmyofascial structures (e.g., iliopsoas), scoliosis,(26) abnormal spinal curvature, and/or unilateral lower extremity pain onweight-bearing
Asymmetric laxity of SIJ during pregnancy may be a cause.(10) (See Clinical Review…Pelvic Pain in Pregnancy ; Topic IDNumber: T708562)
Degenerative hip or knee osteoarthritis (OA) may alter SI joint mobility.(27) Hip OA can lead to leg-length  shorteningassociated with SIJ pain(26)
Repetitive trunk and hip rotational motions(e.g., shoveling)
Activation of the piriformis, biceps femoris, gluteal muscles, erector spinae, latissimus dorsi, and iliacus can aggravate SIJpain(26)
Gout, rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis, and ankylosing spondylitis can cause SIJ inflammation(27)
pathogenesis: The specific anatomical source of pain originating from the SIJ is unclear. Potential pain generators include the SIJ surfaceand the SI ligaments(3,4)

The viscoelastic properties of the SIJ allow only minimal movement. However, when the SI ligaments are sprained orrelax, such as during pregnancy, asymmetric SI mobility may generate pain.(10) Clinically, SIJ dysfunction may be definedas abnormal movement between the sacrum and ilium. The movement may even cause a pelvic obliquity, which is amalalignment resulting in asymmetry between the anatomical position of both ilia. Arthritic pain may follow loosening ofthe ligaments or injury to the irregular articular surface
The SI joint is a pain-sensitive  structure, and because it is so richly innervated SIJ may present in many different ways,with a large variety of referral patterns(26)
risk factors: Although Irwin et al. found that gender, body mass index (BMI), and smoking status were not risks for SIJ dysfunction,women have been suspected of possessing less stable SI joints(4)
Individuals participating in sporting activities that involve significant throwing, kicking, or unilateral loading are at ahigher risk(2)
Women may be at increased risk due to pregnancy
Women may be at increased risk for SI joint problems due to their broader pelvises, greater femoral neck anteversion, andshorter limb lengths(26)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -How long have you been experiencing symptoms? -What were the symptoms at onset and how have they changed since? -Was onset of pain related to trauma, overuse, or pregnancy? -Just prior to the onset of symptoms, what was the position of your body? In what activity were you involved?

course of treatment.medical management: Ask about patient’s past and current medical management, possibly including activity modification and/or bracing with SIJ belt. How has the pain responded to treatment? Surgical intervention is reserved for SIJ pain refractory to conservative care
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Are they effective? NSAIDs are usually prescribed for pain management Corticosteroid injections may be beneficial for sacroiliitis(29)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Structural abnormality rarely is found on radiology evaluation of patients with SIJ dysfunction(8)

Pubic symphyseal changes of OA degeneration and/or vertical displacement may be clearly visualized on an AP view. Together with positive provocative maneuvers and a subjective history of low back pain, this confirmation may prove SIJ disease(39)
Magnetic resonance imaging(MRI) and X-ray  tests may be used to rule out other conditions (e.g., ankylosing spondylitis,(11) malignancy,(8) or fractures)(8)

According to Kok et al., MRI has emerged as the preferred imaging of the SI joint because of multiplanar imaging capability and superior soft tissue and bone marrow contrast on short tau inversion recovery (STIR) and
Isotope bone scintigraphy and lidocaine injection have excellent specificity but poor sensitivity for identifying SIJ dysfunction(29,35,40)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had physical therapy or chiropractic care for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful. Were shoe inserts/lifts ever recommended or used?

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Stair climbing, car transfers, and getting out of a chair are typical aggravating activities. Women with a history of pregnancy-related  SIJ pain often report reoccurrences during menstruation or in a later pregnancy.(4) Does the patient note any pain-relieving  activities or positions?
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Pain may be dull, aching, and/or stabbing -Body chart -Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms -Dermatomal distribution of pain is not consistent with lumbar or sacral nerve root compression and may radiate to groin or lateral thigh. Description or diagram of pain should localize it to buttock area and possibly thigh, but not above L5. A quasi-validated  “pain distribution pattern template” may help in the diagnosis(12)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a V AS or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night related to this condition. In what position does the patient sleep? Does the patient use pillows for positioning?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., persistent night pain, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Previous history of same/similar diagnosis Any history of sudden pain after torsion to the sacral area? Any previous back problems or scoliosis? Any history of back pain during menstruation or a previous pregnancy? Pain with coughing or sneezing? Bowel and bladder dysfunction? Lumbar facet syndrome Lumbar disc herniation Authors of a single group cross-sectional  study (N = 202 patients with proven lumbar disc herniation) found that 72.3% also had at least four positive anatomical and two positive provocative tests for SIJ dysfunction(30)
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders, osteoporosis, genitourinary disorders, etc.
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: How is function affected in occupational, recreational, and daily activities? Are there other contributory problems, such as loss of income or depression? Does patient perform repetitive movements at work or with activities that might be contributing to the problem?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Note any use of assistive devices
social and occupational history.living environment: Ask about stairs, number of floors in home, caregivers, etc.

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Anthropometric characteristicsExcess weight may affect the SIJ and other spinal structures(4)Measure true leg length and compare bilaterally, as leg-length  discrepancy may affect pelvic rotation(13)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Some patients, especially pregnant or postpartum women, may wear an SIJ belt for pain relief. SIJ laxity appears more reduced when the belt is positioned just caudal to the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) than at the level of the pubic symphysis(14)Assess body mechanics; if applicable, assess ergonomics and workstation setup
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess single-leg  stance and note whether sway or pain is increased on one side. If the patient cannot tolerate unilateral stance, can assess in bilateral stance, dynamically and statically, eyes open and eyes closed
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Assess ability to perform functional mobility (including bed mobility, transfers, and stairs) and assess for faulty mechanics that might be contributing to the SIJ problem
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Observe gait for faulty mechanics or asymmetry that may indicate restriction or weakness (e.g., short step length resulting from restricted hip flexor or Trendelenburg due to a weak gluteus medius)Palpation of the SIJ to assess mobility has very poor inter-  and intra-examiner reliability.(15) Lumbar and hip joint mobility should be examined to assist in ruling out other pathologies
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Assess core strength (trunk extension, lateral flexion, rotation, and forward flexion) and side-to-side  strength balance of pelvic stabilizers –Perform thorough assessment of lower-extremity  strength –Leg weakness following a myotomal pattern is an atypical finding and suggests that a lumbosacral condition might be present
observation inspection palpation includi: Assess for tenderness over the posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS), possibly from irritation of the nearby ligaments. Palpate for pain at long posterior SI ligament, sacrotuberous ligament, and short posterior sacroiliac ligament

During assessment, a pelvic obliquity may also be indicated by asymmetry between the right and left ASISs and PSISs.(13) May also need to compare pelvic obliquity in lying and sitting to assist in discerning between a true leg-length discrepancy and a functional leg-length  discrepancy caused by an innominate rotation
Determine if pelvic inflare or outflare, ilial anterior or posterior translation, or sacral flexion or extension abnormalities are present
Also assess for myofascial pain/spasms in pelvic stabilizers, such as the iliopsoas, latissimus dorsi, gluteus maximus, quadratus lumborum, and gluteus medius, and piriformis muscle
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess postural alignment throughout. Compare lower extremities for asymmetry in standing such as excessive hip external rotation and/or foot pronation. In addition to being associated with leg-length  discrepancies, pelvis rotations can also cause scoliosis(13) –Authors of a study (N = 150 neurologic patients with leg-length  discrepancy due to scoliosis) in Finland found that 87% had a reversible pelvic asymmetry. Patients with a C-type  scoliosis had a posterior rotation of the pelvis and an apparent longer leg length on the concavity (ipsilateral) side, whereas patients with an S-type  scoliosis had an ipsilateral anterior rotation of the pelvis with an apparent shorter leg(13)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Muscle tightness and mechanical restrictions in range of motion (ROM) are commonly found in patients with SIJ dysfunction, but no clear pattern of restriction in trunk or hip ROM has been established -Assess trunk ROM, looking for quantity, quality, and reproduction of symptoms during each maneuver. Also consider analyzing the amount of movement occurring at the SIJ via the PSIS during trunk motions(16) -Assess passive hip ROM; take note of quantity and quality of motion, along with the end feel(16) -Determine whether muscle tightness in the hamstrings (straight leg raise test), iliopsoas (Thomas test), or iliotibial band (Ober’s test) is present(16)
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess patellar and Achilles tendon reflexes (usually not affected by SIJ dysfunction but useful for ruling in other conditions) Evaluate as indicated
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Deficits in lower extremity dermatomes are atypical and suggest that a lumbosacral condition might be present
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosiswith the patient supine, the examiner flexes, abducts, and externally rotates the hip on the symptomatic side. A positive result is the reproduction of symptoms in the SI joint area(16)examiner palpates both PSISs as the patient bends forward as far as possible; test positive for asymmetry if PSIS moves further cranially on one side (asymmetric movement is usually observed on the symptomatic side)(17)patient seated with both feet on the floor, examiner palpates both PSISs as the patient forward flexes and tests positive for asymmetry if PSIS moves further cranially on one side. The innominates are fixed in place in sitting, thus isolating out iliac motion(42)the patient is supine with the examiner at foot of the table. After the patient does a bridge maneuver (Weber–Barstow  maneuver) to align the pelvis into neutral, the examiner passively extends the legs of the patient and compares the position of the medial malleoli. The patient is then asked to change to a long sit position, and another comparison of the medial malleoli is performed. A positive result is an observable change in the comparative position of the malleoli and suggests pelvic rotationexaminer alternately palpates right and left PSIS and midline of sacrum at horizontal level of PSIS as patient flexes knee and hip to 90° on the same side of PSIS palpation; test positive for asymmetry if PSIS moves cranially further on one side (usually the painful side) compared to midline of sacrum(17)SIJ pain on three or more of the following tests had a sensitivity and specificity of 94% and 78%, respectively, for SIJ dysfunction compared to intra-articular  anesthetic block injections(15,18)with the patient supine, the examiner applies a posteriorly directed force bilaterally on the ASIS. This results in distraction of both SIJswith the patient side-lying,  a vertical force toward the floor is directed onto the ASIS, which results in compression of both SIJswith the patient supine, one hip on the symptomatic side is flexed to 90° and a posteriorly directed force is applied through the femurpatient lies supine with one leg over the edge of the examination table. Downward overpressure is applied on the leg hanging over the edge while the hip on the contralateral side is flexed with overpressure. The maneuver is performed bilaterallywhile the patient is prone, a downward pressure is applied onto the apex of the sacrum –Oswestry Disability Index (ODI)(31,32) -Authors of a prospective trial (N = 155 patients who received minimally invasive SIJ fusion) in the United States found that ODI scores before and after surgery were a valid measure of disability caused by SIJ pain(36)

contraindications precautions: Hypertension  cold can lead to an increase in blood pressure
Avoid aggressive treatment with cold modalities over an acute wound
Avoid placement over superficial nerves for extended periods (> 1 hour)
May be counterproductive in patients who do not tolerate the modality
Where heat rubs or liniments have recently been used
In patients with cognitive deficits or if a language barrier exists
Stimulation through or across the chest
Used in close proximity to diathermy treatment
other: Patients with SIJ dysfunction are at risk for falls. Follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

Electrotherapy  contraindications/precautions (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician, electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(19)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: SIJ dysfunction/mechanical low back pain associated with pelvic obliquity and/or asymmetric SI joint movement that interferes with general mobility and ADLs
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Ankylosing spondylitis(2,9) Psoriatic arthritis Gynecological pathology Cauda equina syndrome(9) Piriformis syndrome Lumbosacral dysfunction (e.g., radiculopathy, discogenic, zygapophysial)(2) Reactive sacroiliitis(20) Hip joint pathology (e.g., fracture, avascular necrosis, osteoarthritis)(2) Rheumatoid arthritis(2) Myofascial pain(2) Lateral trochanteric bursitis(2)  Malignancy(2,9) Visceral referred pain(2)
prognosis: Pregnancy-related  SIJ dysfunction has a good postpartum prognosis, generally independent of treatment(10)

Authors of a cohort study (N = 69) without controls in the United States found that 95% of patients treated for SIJ pain in a structured pelvic stabilization program (administered by one physical therapist) rated their outcome as good or excellent at a minimum of 2 years follow-up(21)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Chiropractor, osteopathic physician, or physical therapist with manual therapy skills for trial of manual therapy Physician for red-flag  symptoms Emergency services if cauda equina syndrome is suspected Orthopedic surgical consult for CT-guided  SI fusion in recalcitrant cases(22) Orthotist for heel lift or shoe lift if patient has true leg-length discrepancy Neuro-optometrist(32)
other considerations: Authors of a prospective cohort study (N = 61) in Turkey found that corticosteroid injection for treating SIJ pain was effective in the short-term  (day after injection, 1 week, and 3 weeks)for patients with high-grade  arthritis but not at 6 months or 2 years; patients with low-grade  arthritis, however,did experience a long-term benefit(37)

In a case study, an athlete with posture-related  SIJ pain who had undergone multiple interventions (e.g., muscle energy techniques, therapeutic exercises, and chiropractic manipulation) with minimal improvement had complete resolution of symptoms following prescription of prism glasses to improve his spatiotemporal orientation. Visual midline shift syndrome (VMSS) had impaired his posture(32)
treatment summary: Physical therapy treatment for SIJ dysfunction includes therapeutic exercise, manual therapy, cryotherapy, and functional training –Authors of a small randomized controlled trial (RCT) (N = 30) in India found that the ODI decreased 27% in the group that received muscle energy technique (MET) compared to 19% in the group that received traditional physical therapy (i.e., transcutaneous electrical stimulation [TENS] and therapeutic exercise)(23) –For a patient with an anteriorly rotated innominate, MET technique is performed with the patient in supine with the affected hip flexed to 90° with slight external rotation. The patient is asked to extend the affected hip while holding the contraction for 3-4 seconds, while the therapist provides manual resistance(43) –However, authors of another RCT (N = 30) in India found that the MET group and the conventional physical therapy group had similar reductions in pain and ODI. The MET group also demonstrated a return to near normal for functional leg-length  difference(31) –Authors of a case study in South Korea found that 11 sessions of posterior pelvic tilt Kinesio taping improved pelvic inclination and reduced medial buttock pain in an amateur swimmer with LBP related to SIJ dysfunction and increased sacral horizontal angle(33) –Authors of a retrospective study (N = 677) in South Africa found that physiotherapists who had treated the patients for SIJ dysfunction were most likely to use stretches and mobility exercises in combination with joint mobilizations and soft tissue massage for treatment, although evidence was lacking to support the efficacy of any particular intervention(34) –Evidence is lacking on the effectiveness of ultrasound, neuromuscular electrical stimulation, iontophoresis, TENS, and other electrotherapeutic modalities in SIJ dysfunction –Authors of a randomized controlled trial in Korea concluded that gait training with shoe inserts significantly decreased pain in patients with sacroiliac dysfunction(41)

SIJ Belt –Authors of a case-control  study (N = 34) in Germany found that application of a belt had little effect on pelvic morphometry (e.g., alignment of the lumbar spine) using MRI or on 1-leg  standing balance in patients with SIJ dysfunction, although 53% reported a reduction in pain(38) . maintenance or prevention: Continue independent exercise therapy and physical fitness program
Follow proper body mechanics during all functional activities
Continue to wear SIJ belt, if prescribed, during activities that can cause exacerbation of symptoms
